Award.AwardTitle: Why We Persist: An Intersectional Study to Characterize and Examine the Experiences of Women Tenure-Track Faculty in Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. As part of ECR, this project is funded by the Research on Gender in Science and Engineering (GSE) program. GSE seeks to understand and address gender-based differences in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and workforce participation through education and implementation research that will lead to a larger and more diverse domestic STEM workforce. This collaborative project will add to fundamental research in the core area of broadening participation for all women in engineering. It will address the lack of a well-defined body of research methods, studies, and data on the intersection of race, gender, and class among all women. The project will focus on populations that include African American, Hispanic/Latina, Asian/Asian-American, Native American, White, and multiracial women in tenured faculty positions at higher education institutions within the United States. To do this work, collaborative teams of engineering educators, engineers, and social scientists at Purdue University and Vanderbilt University will study challenges and barriers women encounter in engineering. The study will be guided by an intersectional framework that seeks to uncover why engineering faculty from these groups persist despite the challenges that face them based on race, gender, and class.

The proposed study is framed within the institutional (systemic relationships of domination and subordination); symbolic (stereotypical or controlling images); and individual (institutional and symbolic) dimensions of oppression according to Hills Collins' intersectional framework. The project will use mixed methods to identify longitudinal trends in engineering for all women and investigate perspectives about persistence and resilience among the targeted populations. The research will involve descriptive and trend analyses of data collected from 350 institutions by the American Society for Engineering Education, followed a national survey of women selected from the same database. These steps will be augmented by data collected through institutional analyses, a small pilot study, and face-to-face interviews. Interpretation of data culled from these data sources will be triangulated to collectively document unique characteristics, experiences, and factors about oppressions faced by women who persist in engineering. If the outcomes show specific reasons why some women persist, as well as identify barriers to their persistence, the findings could serve as a launching pad for companion studies and the development of interventions. These outcomes could then inform ways to address institutional, symbolic, and individual changes that are fundamental to broadening the participation of all women in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why We Persist: An Intersectional Study Examining the Experiences of Women of Color Tenure-Track Faculty in Engineering

 

Our national survey/scale entitled the Workplace Climate Scale (WCS) for STEM faculty was designed to assess environmental factors at the departmental-level associated with faculty persistence, within a framework of the intersectionality of gender, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic background. The scale constructs include Intrinsic Motivation, Departmental Climate for Diversity, Departmental Climate for Inclusion, Opportunities for Advancement/Promotion, Sense of Belonging, Scholarly Recognition, Mentoring, Work/Life Balance, Finances During Higher Education, and Financial Responsibilities. The confirmatory factor analysis provides evidence indicates that the scale used for engineering faculty persistence is internally consistent. The WCS collected data from over 1,000 tenure-track engineering faculty that explored the concept of intersectionality in two ways. We applied intersectionality as a methodological approach to analyze data based on the survey respondents’ multiple social identities.

 

One manuscript with a quantitative focus entitled “Validation of the Workplace: Climate Scale for STEM Faculty Framed in Intersectionality of Gender, Race/Ethnicity, and Socioeconomic Background” outlines the how we developed the scale and validated the WCS. To provide trends in the prevalence of Women of Color (WoC) faculty and students in engineering, we analyzed data collected from the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE), the National Science Foundation, Integrated Postsecondary Education System, and the American Community Survey. We provided evidence that there is a correlation between the number of WoC faculty and the persistence of WoC undergraduate students in engineering. These results were published in the Journal of Engineering Education in 2020. Another publication: “Trends in the Underrepresentation of Women Faculty of Color in Engineering (2005-2016),” which uses over 10 years of longitudinal data on engineering programs across the member institutions of the American Society for Engineering Education. This study examines trends related to the prevalence of women and WoC faculty in engineering, by race/ethnicity and discipline.

 

We also performed 57 qualitative interviews with tenure-track WoC, who identified as Asian, Black, Latina, and multiracial. These WoC held a variety of ranks within the professoriate, including administrators. Our respondents also represented different engineering disciplines, and different types of institutions such as Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Hispanic Serving Institutions, and Technical Institutes, as well as historically white institutions. We also published in the Journal of Women and Minorities in Science and Engineering, a paper titled “An Intersectional Approach to Investigating Persistence Among Women of Color Tenure-Track Engineering Faculty.” We identified an important factor correlated with the persistence of WoC in academia: supportive colleagues both within the department or institution and external to it. This research also unearthed intersectional considerations revealing group specific nuances unique to Black, Latina, and Asian women engineering faculty members.

 

Another manuscript entitled “Wage Disparities in the Academy: Women of Color, Advocacy, and Agency in Engineering,” interrogates the ways in which pay inequity is often coupled with other forms of exclusion and marginalization for WoC. The findings suggest that WoC must show solidarity with one another when faced with wage inequality and work together to make policy changes. Our manuscript, entitled “An Exploration of How Women of Color Administrators Enter, Disrupt, and Change Higher Education Engineering Environments,” details the trajectory of WoC in administrative positions via social networks, while highlighting how they improve the education engineering environments for students, faculty of color, and women of color. We also demonstrate how the presence of WoC administrators disrupts the white heteropatriarchal structure in some departments and institutions by prioritizing diversity, while also creating systems and providing resources that support a more diverse faculty. Our working paper entitled, “I’ll Still be Here - Factors that Override or Excuse Wage Disparities for Women Engineering Faculty,” describes the most influential factors that undergird persistence among women engineering faculty despite well-known wage disparities. This mixed-method research includes case studies of eight women as well as an analysis of responses from over 600 women engineering faculty who completed the WSC. A mixed methods approach was necessary for uncovering the experiences of WoC tenure-track engineering faculty, since 'this is a neglected area and there are few studies of how and why WoC persist in academia despite the obstacles they face at the intersection of racism, sexism, and classism. Thus, we need an overview of the trends for WoC tenure-track faculty as well as their robust narratives.

 

The WCS has several practical applications. Administrators may use it as a tool to gauge the departmental-level climate related to employee persistence. The evidence we present in our publications regarding WoC engineering professionals will also provide fact-based guidance to engineering Ph.D. programs, engineering faculty search committees, and any organization dedicated to supporting underrepresented groups in these disciplines. When our research program is complete, our body of work will contribute to a more diverse workforce in engineering academia.
